text: I'm the CTO of Ryde Technology

and we're a micro-mobility company
based in Oslo, Norway.

Basically, it's a new way of transporting
and making the communities
and making cities smaller.
Using scooters, you're actively able

to transport yourself
across a city like Oslo in 15 minutes.
Why did we end up choosing AWS?

First of all, the local presence
with the team gave us a lot of confidence
that we were able to do this.

Market leading best practices
on infrastructure was the second

and then the off the shelf
solutions in AI/ML

was just a game changer for us
and what we suddenly understood
that we could achieve.
As a CTO, you always wonder

sort of where you're going
to spend your resources

and how you're going to enable
the business.

Being able to be on AWS,
we're able to keep our team still small,

which saves cost, but it also makes sure
that we can be agile.

So with all the things that we can
sort of pick off the shelf with AWS,

that means we can keep the team still
small and nimble and focus on delivering.

If there is any challenges
that really excites us

or really challenged the industry,
I would say regulation

and working together with municipalities
and with the cities
is going to be a game changer.

Being able to use technology
to better enforce

how users is using micro-mobility,
where do they park?
Where do they ride?
That's going to be a huge mega trend

that is going to demand a lot

So going forward, for our business
is going to be about reaching

that supports that scale.

Working with AWS, being a global player

to enable us to achieve that.
